SubTopics: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole-number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
Content: A bakery sells 5 apple muffins for every 2 bran muffins sold. Which table shows this ratio?

SubTopics: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
Content: In which set do all of the values make the inequality 2x -1 < 10 true?

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: The model below represents a division problem.
problems/NY17G6M/media/3a.jpg
Which equation is represented by the model?

SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Content: What is the value of the expression below?

SubTopics: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Triangle QRS, with vertices Q (6, -2), R (4,-7), and S (2, -5), is drawn inside a rectangle, as shown below.
problems/NY17G6M/media/9a.jpg
What is the area, in square units, of triangle QRS?

SubTopics: Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.
Content: Points F and G have been plotted on the coordinate plane below.
problems/NY17G6M/media/10a.jpg
Point G and point H are the same distance from point F. Which coordinates could be the location of point H?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: A bookstore is selling books for $10 each. Which graph shows the relationship between the number of books, x, the store sold and the total amount of money, y, paid from the book sales?

SubTopics: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole-number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
Content: The ratio of students to adults on a field trip is 8 to 1. Which table correctly shows this ratio for each grade?

SubTopics: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers.
Content: Which phrase is a description of 2m + 7?

C.Choice: 2 times the sum of 7 and m

D.Choice: 7 times the sum of 2 and m

SubTopics: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
Content: George has $23 to spend on art supplies. He wants to buy markers, paper, and glue. If the total cost of the markers and paper is more than $14, which inequality represents the dollar amount, p, George can spend on glue?

SubTopics: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: The net of a rectangular prism is shown below. The surface area of each face is labeled.
problems/NY17G6M/media/17a.jpg
Which values represent the dimensions, in centimeters, of the rectangular prism?

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: A salesperson had $240,000 in sales last year, which is 60% of the sales she had this year. Which equation could be used to determine x, the salesperson's total amount of sales, in dollars, for this year?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
Content: A student formed a pattern in which each term is represented by a sum. The first four terms of the pattern are shown below.
problems/NY17G6M/media/19a.jpg
Which expression can be used to determine the value of the sum in any term, n?

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: Jason will use a 1/3-gallon pitcher to fill an empty 3/4-gallon water jug. How much water will he need in order to completely fill the water jug?

SubTopics: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 5(6x + 3y)?

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: The diagram below shows the percentages of people attending a football game who were supporters of either the home team or the visiting team.
problems/NY17G6M/media/24a.jpg
If the total number of people attending the game was 64,000, how many people were supporters of the home team?

SubTopics: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
Content: Which pair of expressions is equivalent for any variable value greater than zero?

SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Content: What is the greatest common factor of 42 and 84 ?

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: Kira studied data collected on the school basketball team for one season. She noticed that a player on the team had 13 successful free throws out of a total of 20 attempted free throws. To find the percentage of the total free throws attempted by this player that were successful, Kira set up the equivalent ratios below.
What are the values for m and n in Kira's equation?

SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Content: What is the least common multiple of 4 and 10 ?

SubTopics: Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations).
Content: The surface area, S, of a right rectangular prism with length l, width w, and height h can be found using the formula below.
:box:S = 2(lw + wh + hl)
What is the surface area, in square inches, of a prism with a length of 12 inches, a width of 9 inches, and a height of 2 inches?

SubTopics: Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., –(–3) = 3, and that 0 is its own opposite.
Content: Which point on the number line below represents the number opposite the number -5 1/2?
problems/NY17G6M/media/30a.jpg

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: In 2010, Kim-Ly earned $17.50 for 2 hours of work. Which table shows the relationship between the number of hours worked and Kim-Ly's total earnings, if her rate per hour is constant?

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Content: Susan reads a book at a rate of 1 page every 3 minutes. If her reading rate remains the same, which method could be used to determine the number of minutes for her to read 18 pages?

SubTopics: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A triangle has vertices on a coordinate grid at points J (-1, 5), K (4, 5) , and L (4, -2). What is the length, in units, of KL?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
Content: Rosa has a goal of running a total of 100 miles this month. Each day that she ran, she ran 5 miles. Which expression could Rosa use to determine how many miles she has left to run after running for d days?

SubTopics: Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram.
Content: The inequality below compares two rational numbers.
If the two numbers were plotted as values on a horizontal number line, which statement would be true?

A.Choice: Both numbers lie to the right of 0, and -8/18 lies to the left of -17/27.

B.Choice: Both numbers lie to the left of 0, and -8/18 lies to the left of -17/27.

C.Choice: Both numbers lie to the right of 0, and -8/18 lies to the right of -17/27.

D.Choice: Both numbers lie to the left of 0, and -8/18 lies to the right of -17/27.

SubTopics: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
Content: Which value or values for the variable c from the set below will make 5.6 + 0.4c ≤ 6c true?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Steve ordered plastic cases for storing his baseball cards. Each case has a length of 12 centimeters, a width of 6.5 centimeters, and a height of 1.25 centimeters. What is the volume, in cubic centimeters, of one baseball card case?

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b ≠ 0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship.
Content: Kim rode her bicycle 135 miles in 9 weeks, riding the same distance each week. Eric rode his bicycle 102 miles in 6 weeks, riding the same distance each week. Which statement correctly compares the number of miles per week they rode?

A.Choice: Eric rode 2 more miles per week than Kim rode.

B.Choice: Kim rode 3 more miles per week than Eric rode.

C.Choice: Kim rode 11 more miles per week than Eric rode.

D.Choice: Eric rode 17 more miles per week than Kim rode.

SubTopics: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A net of a triangular prism is shown below.
problems/NY17G6M/media/42a.jpg
What is the surface area, in square feet, of the triangular prism?

SubTopics: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
Content: The two expressions below are equivalent.
Which statement best explains why the expressions are equivalent?

A.Choice: The expressions have the same value for any value of y.

B.Choice: The expressions have the same value for only whole number values of y.

C.Choice: The expressions have the same value only when y is an odd number.

D.Choice: The expressions have the same value only when y is an even number.

SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Content: Two whole numbers have a least common multiple of 60.

:box:• Each number is less than or equal to 12.

• The greatest common factor of the two numbers is 2.
What are the two numbers?

SubTopics: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Content: Which quantity could go in the blank to make the equation below true?

SubTopics: Use a pair of perpendicular number lines, called axes, to define a coordinate system, with the intersection of the lines (the origin) arranged to coincide with the 0 on each line and a given point in the plane located by using an ordered pair of numbers, called its coordinates. Understand that the first number indicates how far to travel from the origin in the direction of one axis, and the second number indicates how far to travel in the direction of the second axis, with the convention that the names of the two axes and the coordinates correspond (e.g., x-axis and x-coordinate, y-axis and y-coordinate).
Content: Which coordinate grid shows point M plotted at (4, 3)?

SubTopics: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: What is the area, in square centimeters, of the shaded part of the rectangle shown below?
problems/NY17G6M/media/50a.jpg

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: A sandwich shop sells sandwiches for $5.95 each, including tax. The shop received a total of $71.40 from the sales of sandwiches one afternoon. Which equation can be used to determine the number of sandwiches, x, sold by the sandwich shop that afternoon?
